div.p:
I have the honour to bring to
your notice the state of the Expedition
with which I am entrusted by H.M
Government, & to beg you to take
it with your kind consideration
with a view to render us what
aid may be in your power.

We were detained a long
time at Bombay waiting for the
Man of War appointed by the
Commodore to convey us to the
East Coast - that detention was
not so injurious to us as that which
we have suffered here, for though
the whole party has been provided
liberally for by His Highness the
Sultan, many of us have
suffered severely from fever
& all are daily becoming
physically much less fit
for the arduous duties
before us - This deterioration
arises solely from want of
Employment in an unhealthy
climate - and if we remain
much longer I fear that we
shall be obliged to abandon
the work entrusted to us by
Government.

In addition to the failure of
health in ourselves personally
we have lost ten beasts of
burden - others are sick
& as I know nothing more conducive
to recovery for ourselves &
animals than active Em-
ployment I crave the
favour of your assistance
as far as the Rovuma
& I earnestly hope that
the aid which you can most
effectually render, may not
seriously interfere with your
other duties on the coast.
From the uniform readiness
with which the Admiralty
have always granted me
all the assistance in their
power I feel positive that
their Lordships would promptly
approve of your lending me a
helping hand -
